In this lesson we will practise two sentence patterns. One is for asking for permission, using the "te" form of the verb plus "mo ii desu ka". The other forbids an action, using the "te" form of the verb plus "ha ikemasen". We will look at making sentences in both question and statement forms. The patterns and forms you will be expected to know to complete this lesson are summarised below:

japanese.content: 窓を開けてもいいですか

translated.content: "Do you mind if I open the window?"(Permission)

japanese.content: ここで煙草を吸ってはいけません

u.b: Grammar Point 1: Giving and Asking for Permission

grammar_points.p: For sentences that give permission to perform an action, you change the verb into the "te" form and add the marker "mo" plus the phrase "ii desu". This is equivalent to the expressions "You may..." or "You can..." in English. You can ask permission to perform an action by adding the question marker "ka" to the statement form.

tr.td: コーヒーを飲んでもいいです - "You may drink coffee."
この本を読んでもいいです - "You can read this book."
テレビを見てもいいですか - "Do you mind if I watch TV?"
ここでたばこを吸ってもいいですか - "May I smoke here?"

grammar_points.p: An expression similar to the one above is used to forbid an action. In this case, the grammar pattern is the "te" form of the verb followed by the topic marker "ha" plus the word "ikemasen".

tr.td: 窓を開けてはいけません - "You may not open the window."
ここで車を止めてはいけません - "You cannot park your car here."

grammar_points.p: This form can also be turned into a question by adding the question marker "ka". However, in this case the nuance is slightly different. Questions of this form express the speaker's assumption that the listener will not give permission for the action.

tr.td: ここでたばこを吸ってはいけませんか - "Am I not allowed to smoke here?"
ビールを飲んではいけませんか - "Am I not allowed to drink beer?"
